Award.AwardTitle: Examining How Exposure to Metaphorical Framing Influences Attitudes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: People routinely encounter TV, radio and web messages that compare an abstract and complicated issues to a simpler, more concrete concept. For example, a new report that the economy veered off course compares the abstract economy to a simpler vehicle, while the headline "Banks Tighten Their Grip" compares complicated banking policies to physical grasping. The current project is based on conceptual metaphor theory, which predicts that metaphors are not simply a matter of words: rather, they are a tool of thought that people use to understand abstract concepts. It is expected that metaphorical framings are not simply interpreted as mere figures of speech, but have an important and predictable influence on how people think and feel about issues.

Eight experiments test the hypothesis that exposure to metaphorical framing will lead people to form attitudes toward an issue by drawing on their knowledge of the concrete concept to which it is compared, despite the fact that the issue and the concrete concept are unrelated.

One important implication of metaphorical framing theory is that metaphorical framing will have a greater or lesser impact on attitudes depending on how the person initially understands the attitude. The proposed experiments therefore test the hypothesis that volunteers who are initially led to focus on vague and complicated aspects of an issue will be more likely to rely on a metaphorical framing to form their attitudes than are volunteers who are initially led to focus on clear and simple aspects of the issue. The proposed experiments also test the hypothesis that metaphorical framings are less influential when they do not match a person?s prior conceptualization of the topic.

Overall, the proposed research will help us better understand how everyday communications, many of which are based on metaphors, influence everyday thinking. In addition, students will receive training and experience in conducting scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The concepts that make up our sociopolitical lives—such as freedom, the economy, and evil—are typically abstract and difficult to define. It is therefore not surprising that metaphors are commonly used in public discourse to communicate about them. For example, a newspaper headline compares power to a tight grip, while a political cartoon depicts immigration as a tidal wave. Less understood, however, is the potential impact such metaphors have on the way people make sense of the major issues facing society.

To fill this gap, this project built on Conceptual Metaphor Theory’s claim that metaphor is not only a figure of speech, but is also a cognitive tool that people can use to understand an abstraction in terms of a superficially dissimilar, more concept. At a process level, metaphor shapes thought by applying knowledge of a concrete concept as a framework for representing and reasoning about the abstraction, despite their superficial differences.

The broad goal of this project was to investigate metaphor’s significance on sociopolitical cognition through a programmatic series of laboratory experiments. Two specific objectives were:

--  Test whether exposure to metaphors in public discourse activate metaphors in observers’ minds. If so, they should lead observers to transfer knowledge of a metaphor’s concrete concept to interpret analogous aspects of the target abstraction.

-- Test when metaphor exposure influences target attitudes. Although metaphors pervade sociopolitical discourse, political attitudes are relatively stable, suggesting that metaphor’s potential influence depends on situational factors.

These objectives guided the articulation of several hypotheses tested in over a dozen experiments conducted with demographically diverse samples recruited from undergraduate and community populations. Taken as a whole, the results of these experiments provide robust evidence that metaphoric messages have statistically and practically significant consequences for political attitudes.

One illustrative study focused on a metaphor comparing the failure of a social system to a vehicle accident, as reflected in expressions like “the committee is veering off track.” Does this metaphor guide judgments about responsibility for system failure? To find out, we asked participants how strongly they believe that vehicle accidents are solely the fault of the vehicle’s driver compared to the passengers or driving conditions. Weeks later they read a news report describing a corporate bankruptcy in either vehicle-metaphoric terms or equivalent literal terms. Among those exposed to the vehicle metaphor, the degree to which they blamed drivers for causing vehicle accidents positively predicted how much they blamed the company’s CEO—the single, highest-ranking individual in charge of that system (Figure 1). In contrast, driver blame beliefs did not predict their blaming of the company’s employees or the economic milieu. Among participants exposed to a literal description, driver blame beliefs did not predict blame attributions. This and related studies show that even incidental exposure to metaphoric messages prompts observers to transfer knowledge of concrete concepts to interpret analogous aspects of unrelated issues—even those aspects which are not explicitly referred to in the original message.

Studies addressing the second objective built on Conceptual Metaphor Theory’s claim that metaphor use serves a psychological function, satisfying the motivation to gain a confident grasp of an otherwise nebulous concept. This suggests that when people feel as though they lack a confident understanding of an idea, they will embrace a metaphor that grounds it in something else familiar. If, in contrast, they feel as though they understand the target issue, they will not rely on a provided metaphor. Consistent with this analysis, one study revealed that framing a bankruptcy metaphorically as a vehicle accident (versus literally) led participants to focalize blame to the company’s CEO—its “driver”—but only if they were previously led to feel uncertain about the causes of corporate bankruptcy (Figure 2). Those led to feel more confident in their knowledge of bankruptcy did not later embrace the provided metaphor to interpret who was to blame.

Other studies demonstrate theoretically-specified effects of metaphor exposure on attitudes toward several controversial issues, including sex discrimination, immigration, and economic crises. Findings establish boundary conditions of these effects, shedding light on how, when, and for whom metaphors shape judgments. At a theoretical level, these discoveries help elucidate the cognitive mechanisms underlying political cognition. At a practical level, they highlight the importance of attending to the particular metaphors individuals and groups use to frame discourse. This work also informs interventions designed to relax reliance on certain metaphors, or replace them with more socially constructive alternatives, with the goal of improving intergroup and interpersonal relations.

The conduct of these studies satisfied other goals. Graduate students received professional training and career advancement. Undergraduates were afforded opportunities for hands-on participation in scientific research. Finally, the findings were continually disseminated to the research community and the public at large in the form of conference presentations, research reports, and books.
